title: Graham's GCD Conjecture
description: For any finite set A ⊂ ℕ, there exist a, b ∈ A such that gcd(a, b) ≤ a/|A|. Graham's conjecture was proved by Balasubramanian and Soundararajan in 1996.

overview.historicalContext: This problem originated as a conjecture of Graham (1970). Szegedy (1986) and Zaharescu (1987) independently proved it for sufficiently large sets. Balasubramanian and Soundararajan (1996) completed the proof for all finite sets.
overview.problemStatement: For any finite set A ⊂ ℕ with positive elements, prove there exist a, b ∈ A such that gcd(a, b) ≤ a/|A|.
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the main statement and prove special cases: singleton sets, the Graham special set {2,3,4,6}, and derive a key lemma that coprime pairs suffice when |A| ≤ a.
keyInsights: The bound gcd(a,b) ≤ a/|A| is tight for certain families
For coprime elements, gcd = 1 which is ≤ a/|A| when |A| ≤ a
The Graham special set {2,3,4,6} achieves equality with gcd(4,3)=1 and 4/4=1

sections.title: Main Statement
sections.summary: Graham's GCD Conjecture: for any finite set A, there exist elements with small gcd.

sections.title: Equivalent Formulation
sections.summary: The minimum gcd ratio is at most 1/|A|.

sections.title: The {2, 3, 4, 6} Example
sections.summary: Graham's special set that achieves equality in the bound.

sections.title: Graham's Equality Characterization
sections.summary: The only primitive sets achieving equality are three specific families.

sections.title: Key Lemmas
sections.summary: Coprime elements suffice; singleton containing 1 works.

conclusion.summary: We formalize Graham's GCD Conjecture (Erdős #402). For any finite set A of positive integers, there exist a, b in A with gcd(a,b) ≤ a/|A|. The proof was completed by Balasubramanian and Soundararajan in 1996.
conclusion.implications: This result connects combinatorial properties of finite sets to the structure of their greatest common divisors, with applications in additive combinatorics.
openQuestions: Can the proof be made more constructive?
What is the computational complexity of finding the optimal pair (a,b)?
Are there generalizations to other algebraic structures?
